newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka approves 13 new TV and radio stations.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka approves 13 new TV and radio stations.

text.p: The Sri Lankan government has granted approval to eight new private television networks and five new radio stations, Media Minister Mangala Samaraweera told parliament on Tuesday.
Samaraweera said in reply to a question that the ruling People's Alliance government had received applications for 18 television networks and 14 radio stations since it came to power in late 1994.
"We have already issued licences for 13 stations, radio and television," he said.
None of the approved television and radio stations have started operations.
The tiny Indian Ocean island currently has eight television stations -- all but two of them owned by private investors -- and about a dozen radio stations, most of them privately owned.
In April, the government introduced in parliament a bill to set up a broadcasting authority with wide powers to monitor, regulate and grant operating licences to broadcasters.
But the bill was ruled unconstitutional by the Supreme Court after media organisations challenged it in court.

Samaraweera, who replaced Dharmasiri Senanayke as media minister last week, also made changes in the government media by appointing new directors to the boards of the state-owned radio and television networks.
He has also brought in new people to run Associated Newspapers, which publishes the island's biggest-selling English-language newspaper, The Daily News, among other publications.
